author: Trevor Hoey
title: South32 struggles for traction in opening quarter
text:
Analysts at UBS and Deutsche Bank slightly downgraded forward earnings projections for South32 but both maintained a buy recommendation on the stock. by Trevor Hoey Analysts at Deutsche Bank described South32's debut quarterly production results, released last week, as solid, particularly given the tough operating environment in South Africa.
From a positive perspective the broker noted manganese and thermal coal volumes were up and aluminium broadly flat, despite load shedding and maintenance issues.
While South32 chief executive Graham Kerr fleshed out the various aspects of the result, rather than looking backwards his focus appeared to be on how they pertained to the company's culture in the future.
He highlighted the curtailment of aluminium production at Alumar and manganese alloy production at Metalloys demonstrated management's commitment to maximising financial performance per share rather than volume.
He underlined the group's high-quality assets, cash-generating capacity and strong balance sheet, which he indicated would enable the company to establish a strong foundation for its agile and entrepreneurial culture. In terms of shareholder returns, he committed to a distribution of at least 40 per cent of underlying earnings in 2015-16.
Analysts at UBS and Deutsche Bank slightly downgraded forward earnings projections but both maintained a buy recommendation on the stock. Their price targets of $2.45 (Deutsche Bank) and $2.30 (UBS) represent a significant premium to the group's recent trading range.
It is worth noting South32 hasn't traded above $2.45 since listing on the ASX in May, following the demerger from BHP. Since mid-June the company has traded consistently at less than $2.
Deutsche Bank said South32 represented "compelling value" at current levels, with the broker's positive take on the stock underpinned by its clean balance sheet, positive free cash flow at spot prices and the potential for acquisitions.
 Deutsche also regards South32 as well positioned for the current environment, given its heavy exposure to aluminium/alumina, at 62 per cent of earnings before interest and tax based on UBS estimates.
